Nursing staff will be on campus during summer school and available for questions from 8-12. Also feel free to reach out via email or SeeSaw for PreK -5th grade students.

Ms. Rachel Simons has achieved Advanced Board Member Certification from the Missouri School Boards' Association.

Dear Parent or Guardian,

The Tooth Truck provides comprehensive treatment, from cleanings and x-rays, to repairing cavities at no charge for qualifying families. Requirements for being seen and treated on the Tooth Truck are:

-Be between the ages of 3-18 years
-Qualify for the free and reduced lunch program at school
-Cannot be an established patient of a local dentist
-Cannot have private dental insurance
-Must complete a Tooth Truck application form

The Tooth Truck treats Medicaid-eligible and uninsured children. Children seen last year are not eligible for a routine check up but should apply if there is a new dental concern.
Please complete an application form and return to the school nurse as soon as possible. Applications can be accessed online at https://rmhcozarks.org/tooth-truck/tooth-truck-patient-application/

The Tooth Truck staff will be scheduling students very soon.

Thank You,

Your School Nurse

A Message from the Superintendent

The safety of our students is our number one priority. From the time a student steps onto a bus until he or she arrives home, we are responsible for their well being. With that in mind, I would like to take this opportunity to remind parents/guardians that end-of-day transportation changes must be communicated with appropriate office personnel in a timely manner.

Notice of changes must be received in the appropriate office no later than 2:00 p.m. (or 12:00 p.m. on early release Fridays) to ensure communication to the student. Messages must be accurately logged and delivered to each student with end-of-day changes, and any messages received after the cutoff time negatively affect our ability to do so.

Please note these guidelines have already been in place for the safety of our students, and this is a reminder that the cutoff time will be strictly enforced moving forward. Thank you for your partnership regarding this matter!

The Clever baseball team isn't waiting until baseball season to get to work! Coach Justin Snider has organized a book study on The Power of a Positive Team by Jon Gordon. Each team member received a copy of the book. They are reading it independently and meeting periodically to discuss.

Coach Snider tells us "I believe that when you look at teams who win championships they all have a positive team culture at the top of their attributes. We were looking to take our kids, and our program, to that next level. Jon Gordon's books exemplify these concepts and his book, The Power of a Positive Team, will hopefully help guide our kids not just mentally, but as athletes, the classroom and life as well."

post_text: October 21-25 is National School Bus Safety Week. Monday through Friday, our buses transport the most valuable resource on this planet--our students. Bus safety is not just important, it's vital to the safety of the children of our community. Did you know that the American School Bus Council estimates that over 10 million drivers illegally pass school buses every year? Our drivers work diligently to keep every child safe, and we appreciate your support. We encourage everyone to Slow, Stop, and Stay--Slow when you see a school bus with flashing yellow lights, Stop a safe distance away when the stop arm is out and the flashing red lights are on, and Stay where you are until all children have crossed safely and the bus is once again moving. No matter what, children's safety is always the #1 priority!

We Have Lift-off!
This year is the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing. The vast majority of our faculty/staff were not even born when this event took place, but we can all marvel and wonder at the pioneering work the courageous men and women put into this mission.
We can also celebrate the creativity and hard work of our high school administrators and teachers who are using this anniversary to plan a unit focused on the Apollo 11 mission. Every teacher has developed a project or activity revolving around some aspect of the moon landing.
To kick things off, today the entire high school gathered in the performing arts center to watch an Apollo 11 documentary. On October 30th, these events will culminate with a showcase for the community from 4:00 - 8:00 p.m. at CHS. Students will be on hand to present their work and discuss what they learned and the processes they went through.
Mark the date on your calendar, and join us as we celebrate both the anniversary of a historic event and the collaborative efforts of a great group of students and teachers!

All 8th grade students must have proof of immunizations on file with the school nurse before attending school. If attending summer school, student must be compliant with updated shot record on file with the school nurse by the first day of summer school. The first day of summer school is May 28, 2019.

Thank you,
